Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: While I enjoyed learning techniques for solving problems requiring multivariate calculus, the greatest appreciation I developed through this course was for elegance and rigor in explanations.  Writing out my solutions has improved my ability to write clear/unambiguous explanations conciselya skill that has proven useful in other courses and academic endeavors as well.
solving problems with multivariable calculus
Multivariable calculus and the various theorems needed for physics

I learned about applying calculus to functions of multiple variables. These concepts will likely be helpful in future physics and engineering courses. Additionally, it was interesting to learn about the various path and surface integrals and what they mean.

I certainly learned the necessary skills for how to properly study for a college level math exam. I also honed my time management skills in completing the psets. Furthermore, I really felt like I came away, having a deep understanding of the concepts taught.

This course significantly broadened my understanding of multivariable and vector calculus.  This course was especially helpful because it focused on the subtleties of the material.  I also learned how to study well from taking this course.

Other than the courses content, I developed critical thinking by learning how to apply functions in context. Through conceptual multiple choice questions, I lerarned not only to plug and chug but also to thoroughly understand what each functions importance was.
Seems to mostly have applications in physics. Would definitely look elsewhere for a math class if physics doesn't appeal to you.
I learned the fundamentals of multi-variable calculus, which should serve me well in a number of possible different majors and fields in the future.
Ability to reason through problems and gain better critical thinking skills

I had to learn how to distribute the work throughout the week, because it was a lot to learn all at once. I also had to learn how important it was to stay on top of the work, especially conceptually, because it was far too much to try to catch up on before a midterm or final.
You will definitely learn a LOT about calculus in this course!

I gained study skills in terms of learning how to structure my problem-solving practice to  more deeply learn the material after sitting through lectures. I also gained an understanding of multi variable calculus, but I felt like my conceptual understanding suffered when we focused on more formulaic problems and didn't deeply explore proofs for our theorems.

There need to be two levels of this class. 70% of the kids have taken multi before. As somebody who did not have access to this course in high school, it was an uneven playing field. As good as a teacher as Miki was, it does not make up for being curved against kids who have taken this class before.

I honed my quantitative and analytical skills while learning how to evaluate line integrals and surface integrals with multiple techniques. I gained problem solving skills and insight to new mathematical properties and ideas and conceptualizations in the practical world.
Strengths: good teachers, good tutors

There are many resources to help students prepare for exams and keep up with the course. However, different professors have drastically different ways of explaining key concepts, so attending reviews for exams can actually cause unnecessary confusion.

The content of the course is strong and well developed; I very much appreciated the detailed derivations we walked through for each concept we discussed (much more gratifying than simply accepting formulae on faith).  Having more class time to cover the content may be beneficial.

The class moves very quickly, and there are clearly a lot of students who have taken multivariable calculus before, so it's easy to fall behind. I think this course would benefit from a discussion section.

Strength: weekly psets reinforce learning, high availability of peer tutor office hours, a lot of review sessions before the final exam

Weakness: Lecture was not engaging because professor goes over material too quickly and does not give students time to think about/ try solving problems before she gives you the solution. Most of the peer tutors, except Calvin Schwartzberg, don't know the material well enough. Exams are graded very harshly and there is hardly any curve.

The course is well-taught and the problem sets are a great opportunity to solidify skills. One suggestion I would have would be to increase the weight of problem sets from 10% to something like 20%. The sheer volume of problem sets that had to be completed feels like more than 10%.

I think the curriculum of the course is very good. One critique I have is the amount of computation. For example, setting up a triple integral, was very challenging and fun to figure out. However, we were then left to solve it, which could leave us with a page of seemingly mindless computations. One thing that perhaps could be cool, would be integrating this class with a computer science class, where the students could be challenged to write computer programs to solve the long computations after setting up the integrals.

It is excellent how much material this course covers, but I wish there was a way to do more problems in small groups in class.  This was very helpful towards the end of the semester, but it would have helped at the beginning as well.  Perhaps there were several not quite essential examples that could have been skipped in class or given to the students to attempt on their own.

Some strengths are that the review sessions really helped to tie every concept together, especially with the flowcharts that Sudesh and Miki made. I also really loved Mikis teaching style, because even though it went by pretty quickly, she gave a lot of examples and explained concepts in multiple ways that made it easier to understand. One weakness would probably be that there was not enough time for students to work out problems on their own during class. However, this was only so probably because there was so much material to cover in such a short amount of time. To improve this, perhaps give students practice problems before every class and have a perhaps 5-10 period at the beginning of class going over these problems. That way, students can know if they are on track before doing the problem sets.

The course does a good job of offering comprehensive review sessions and study materials for tests. However, I think the tests are focused on not messing up on difficult integration rather than focusing on understanding the material itself. The majority of the points awarded are for correctly doing integrals, not necessarily setting them up.
This course could be improved by reevaluating the course syllabus so that less information is taught. It could also be improved by requiring sections to meet three times a week instead of twice.

I think the course should be taught with more of a mission to really try to connect the dots. The concepts were taught well, but the relationship between them and the big picture view of the information was not made very clear, at least to me. I think that would enormously improve the course.

I think the course could be improved if the problem sets were structured differently.  If they work more focused on the exam content, or the questions the teacher want us to know how to solve, it would be much more useful.  That way maybe they could count for more and take a bit of weight away from the final.

The class moves very quickly, and it is easy to become confused early on and have a hard time catching up. I think the course could benefit from meeting three times a week rather than just two, and from working through problems in small groups in class sometimes rather than just lecturing. There were lots of opportunities to ask questions every day in lecture though which was very helpful in a class with such a quick pace.

Miki is great-- really supportive, clear, and accessible to her students-- and in general the structures for getting help (office hours and the peer tutor office hours) are very well organized and helpful. I just didn't find this class as exciting and creative or engaging as math can be.
Make two levels of this course
I think that grading is a little confusing but I think Miki is an amazing teacher.
The information is presented in bulk and without much check-in of the students' understanding.

The strength of this course was the teacher, Miki Havlickova. She explained everything so beautifully and made very complex, difficult topics so easy to understand. She is an amazing instructor and an inspiring woman in math. 

There was no weakness in this course in my opinion.

I would prefer if the final exam counted for less than 40% of the final grade, and more importance were shifted to the midterms. It would help with stress levels to be working at a more or less constant level throughout the semester, rather than freaking out at the end about a single test.
Yes; this course is very interesting and well planned-out
If you are interested in learning multivariate calculus, this course is challenging and rewarding.  If you invest in learning the material, this course is very worthwhile.

If it is a prereq to your classes, then yes take it, but do not have high expectations of getting a good grade. if you don't have to, don't take it because you will be competing with people who have already taken multivariable calculus before in high school
I would recommend this course to another student for sure (especially if he or she can get Miki). The course was a great way to start my freshman year and was very manageable and interesting.

Yes, I think I learned a tremendous amount. Again, my only complaint was the amount of computation during some of the homeworks. Other than that, I think the class prepared me very well for the next level courses.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because it is a great way to thoroughly learn multivariable and vector calculus.  Even if you think you already know this material, this course is an excellent way to deepen your understanding and tie up any loose ends.

Yes! The problem sets are a little challenging at times, but if you have a good group of people to work on them with, they are not that bad. Miki made the course worthwhile, so definitely try to take it with her if you can!
PLEASE do not take this class unless it is a requirement for your major! Tests are stressful (and worth 90% of your grade) and grading is very stiff.

I would recommend it only insofar as they need to take multi-variable calculus at some point. The course is not the most interesting or fun, so I think other math classes or classes in other subjects are better if a student is looking for a more stimulating and engaging class.

I think this course is definitely geared toward students who enjoy math and are driven enough to handle the rigor. It's not for the faint of heart. I took this class during my first semester of my first year, and I realize that it was a bit too much for me to handle. I did, however, come to the realization that I do not in fact want to major in math, and I do not regret taking the course. Just be aware when entering that the course is fast-paced. If you can, take it with Miki! She's an excellent instructor.
I would recommend this course if they really enjoy math, and are ready to devote time to it. It is not a course you can coast through, and it is very necessary to stay on top of all of the work.
I would recommend it only if it is a requirement or you really really love math.  It is not easy!
This class is very hard, so I wouldn't take it unless you need to. However, you will learn a lot throughout the semester, and it is a prerequisite for many majors.
If you need it for your major, yes, and take advantages of all the resources that the course offers. If not, no-- it might unfairly disillusion you with math as being something creative and awesome.
Take it if there two levels. Otherwise take ENAS 151
I would recommend the course because it provides the student with a set of theorems and techniques that are very useful in terms of multivariable calculus.

Yes, I definitely would! If you are lucky enough to receive to Miki as your instructor, cherish the time you have with her because she makes you love math, even when it gets difficult. I learned so much in this class, and it was an exciting journey. I definitely feel that I have grown tremendously as a math student and as a student in general through this class.
